greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: For odd n, a(n) = 2; for even n, a(n) = denominator of Bernoulli(n)/n; The number 2 alternating with the elements of A006953.
comment: There is an integer sequence b(n) = A053657(n)/2^(n-1) = 1, 1, 6, 6, 360, 360, 45360, 45360, 5443200, 5443200,... which consists of the duplicated entries of A202367.
The ratios of this sequence are b(n+1)/b(n) = 1, 6, 1, 60, 1, 126 .... = a(n)/2, which is a variant of A036283.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
formula: a(n) = Product_{d|n} [(1+d)^(1+A286561(n,1+d))]^A010051(1+d) - after _Peter J. Cameron_'s Mar 25 2002 comment in A006863.
mathematica: max = 52; s = Expand[Normal[Series[(-Log[1-x]/x)^z, {x, 0, max}]]]; a[n_, k_] := Denominator[Coefficient[s, x^n*z^k]]; A053657 = Prepend[LCM @@@ Table[a[n, k], {n, max}, {k, n}], 1]; a[n_] := A053657[[n+1]]/A053657[[n]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, max}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 20 2012 *)
program: (PARI) A185633(n) = { my(m=1); fordiv(n, d, if(isprime(1+d), m *= (1+d)^(1+valuation(n,1+d)))); (m); }; \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 03 2018
results.author: _Paul Curtz_, Dec 18 2012
